results.title: High voltage
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and SEC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
Building Victoria’s 500KV system: recounts the building of Victoria’s 500KV line for power transfer from the Yallourn Power Station to Melbourne. Shows planning and testing of towers, film of actual construction of line land clearing and excavation of sites for towers. The film describes some of the planning and construction of the 500KV line - designed to carry power from the future generating stations of the Latrobe Valley to the local centre in Melbourne. Shows rolling out and cutting of the power cabling, installation of equipment at Hazelwood Plant, preparation and countdown for energizing in June, 1970. Photography by Jim Hayes. “Along the power lines” (1962): dramatised account of the work of the mobile repair units of the SEC. Shows film of the irrigation reservoir at Eildon and pipelines at Kiewa, power lines crossing the Murray River Valley joining New South Wales with Victoria and the various parts involved in the process of electricity production from brown coal. Footage of the power plants and lines shows inside the control centre near Melbourne, with the technicians at work monitoring the load on supply. Photography by John Leake with aerial photography by Jim Hayes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and SEC

results.title: Coal Power
results.brief_description: Includes “Power from the Valley”, outlining the process of brown coal mining in the La Trobe Valley and its eventual consumption in a turbine generator. (12 min) “Demolition of Yallourn Briquette Chimney” looks at the demolition of the historic briquette production plant at yallourn. Directed by Jim Hayes. (4 min) “The Timeless Force” is a history of the harnessing of energy and its eventual application by the SEC. Gives a history of the SEC’s early years. This film narrated by John Stanton. (29 min)

(4 min) “The Timeless Force” is a history of the harnessing of energy and its eventual application by the SEC. Gives a history of the SEC’s early years. This film narrated by John Stanton. (29 min)

group_siblings.title: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

results.title: Celebrations
results.brief_description: Features two films recounting the history and development of the SEC. “Fifty Years of Service” focuses on the history of electricity in Victoria from the late 1800’s to the development of the SEC in 1919. Highlights the achievements of Sir John Monash, the first General Manager and Chairman of the SEC. Looks at the development of power plants at Yallourn, Morwell, Hazelwood and Kiewa. Examples of the impact of electricity on domestic life at the time is shown with new appliances such as hair dryers and vacuum cleaners entering the home. (33 min) “Generations of Power” is another historical retrospective this time with comments from several SEC staff members from between the 1940’s to 1990’s. Includes a decade by decade look at the impact of electricity on Victorian Society. (23 min)

results.title: 1960's productions
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, SECV and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
This tape is a compilation of 4 programs: “The Briquette story”: Explains the formation of brown coal and its processing into briquettes at the Yallourn open cut. Using the vehicle of a young couple selecting appropriate heating for their new home. The program outlines the convenience and versatility of briquettes for heating, cooking and hot water generation. The value of briquettes in commercial and industrial usage is also explained. “Valley of power” (prod. writer, Shan Benson): Looks at the importance of the Latrobe Valley, site of the world’s largest single brown coal field, to Victoria. Outlines the economic and lifestyle benefits that the power industry and its supporting infrastructure has brought to the towns of Yallourn, Traralgon, Moe and Morwell. Includes commentary from local identities Willis Connolly, Les Haine, Campbell Husten and Mrs Thompson. “Power makers” (dir. Lee Robinson): Looks at a typical day in the life of four “power makers” - workers at the Yallourn power station. We are shown the important work performed by dredger crews, train drivers, boiler hands, turbine attendants and other tradesmen. Features workers George Fisher, Jack Morris, Rowley Paul and Frank Robertson. “Behind the switch”: Every switch is a demand for instant electricity. The Latrobe Valley brown coal provides four-fifths of electricity. Shows work at Yallourn and Morwell and progress on the new Hazelwood power station. Use of electricity in industry, at home, for transport, and entertainment. Increasing demands are a measure of the State’s growth and rate of development. Emphasis on ability to meet future demands.

results.title: 1950's productions
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
This tape is a compilation of 4 programs: “Brown coals to briquettes”: Classroom film showing the manufacture of briquettes at Yallourn and Morwell, Victoria. Includes demonstration by models of processes; operation of coal dredges at open cut; crushing and drying of coal; pressing of fine powder into briquettes; transport of finished product to other parts of Victoria. “Brown coal to kilowatts”: Classroom film describing the processes by which wet, raw brown coal from the Yallourn open cut is burned in specially designed boilers to produce steam for use in turbines for the generation of electric power. Laboratory demonstration, models, and diagrams explain the principles of operation of plant seen in use at Yallourn. “Romance of brown coal”: Illustrates how brown coal has been formed in the Latrobe Valley. Also shows the mining of brown coal and the conveyance of the coal from the open cut to the power house and briquetting plant. “Pageant of power”: Looks at open-cut mining and processing of brown coal at Yallourn, both for power generation and briquette production. Creation of Yallourn as an exemplary company town, plus references to early hydro-electric power stations located in north eastern Victoria.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria

results.title: My country: right or wrong? [Extract from 'Summertree']
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
An extract from the feature film “Summertree” produced by Kirk Douglas and directed by Anthony Newley. Raises issues concerning the individual, patriotism and family relationships. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Dehumanizing city...and Hymie Schultz
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hiller, George Justin, Learning Corporation of America and Colombia Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Adapted from the film “The Tiger makes out” with Eli Wallach, the theme here is the modern individual in conflict with complex bureaucratic systems. Waking up one morning to the callous impersonality of big city life, Hymie Schultz, mailman, decides to fight back. Bureaucracy, however, proves more stubborn than he, and at the end of the day defeated and helpless, he retreats, one individual lost among many.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Hiller, George Justin, Learning Corporation of America and Colombia Pictures

results.title: Whether to tell the truth
results.creator_credit: Elia Kazan, Sam Spiegel, Learning Corporation of America and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Specially edited from “On the Waterfront”, produced by Sam Spiegel, directed by Elia Kazan, this film explores the theme of conscience and conflicting loyalties. It tells of a young man who painfully gains a sense of himself and of his duty to society at the cost of losing his friends and a familiar way of life. As a dock worker, Terry Malloy is bribed by his bosses to suppress information about the murder of a co-worker in which he had inadvertently taken part. Influenced by the parish priest and his own conscience he makes testimony and is left an outcast by his fellow workers. Based on the novel by Budd Schulberg. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elia Kazan, Sam Spiegel, Learning Corporation of America and Columbia Pictures

results.title: The Fine art of aggression
results.creator_credit: Jack Gold, Ronald Shedlo and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Presents a story of one man’s ruthless determination to succeed in business at the expense of his co-workers. Shows how destruction of self and others results when an unthwarted will goes beyond the norms of reason. Edited from the Columbia Pictures 1969 motion picture entitled “The Reckoning”.

description_for_label:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Presents a story of one man’s ruthless determination to succeed in business at the expense of his co-workers. Shows how destruction of self and others results when an unthwarted will goes beyond the norms of reason. Edited from the Columbia Pictures 1969 motion picture entitled “The Reckoning”.

results.title: Love to kill
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kramer and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Specially edited from “Bless the beasts and children”. Raises issues surrounding the right to kill, the right to carry and use firearms, and the morality of taking the law into your own hands. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Kramer and Learning Corporation of America
